title: How to write like Hemingway - Quora

response.answer_text: How to write like and in the style of another author is easier when one is in love with the authors work/s, stories , characters, places, theme and style. Robert Louis Stevenson [1] and R F Delderfield [2] never knew each other. Delderfield as a boy fell in love with Robert Louis Stevenson’s Treasure Island story. When he started reading the story he loved to his children he became bewitched by their questions and their shared fascination about; what happens to who after the story ends? Delderfield’s children’s awe and rapture over the thrilling adventures of Pirates on the high seas left poor old Mr Delderfield with no choice but to write the sequel and answer some of their questions like; What happened to Ben Gun? And so Mr D wrote the book; Ben Gun. Mr D’s passion paid off in my view as Benn Gunn’s story is invisibly faithful to the style and work of RLS’s Treasure Island. If pirates and fuddy duddy dead writers don’t capture your heart no worries. Contemporary sequel writing is a tried and tested technique of putting food on the table for writers and helps to keep their writing fresh and interesting and worth falling in love over ♪○♥○♪. PS. I love Ernest’s work also. I’ve read “The old man of the seas”. Three times, at least? Another favourite of mine is John Steinbeck’s; Cannery row. He knew how to milk his own work in a similar fashion as he grew to love his own characters. He became frustrated for the want of having their voices heard as well. So he re-wrote it. From the beginning again using another of his characters perspectives to write; He began the follow up/re-telling of the story in Sweet Thursday with this line; “ If I had to tell the full story of Cannery Row I would of written it like this instead…” Something like that anyway both books are brilliant! No one can help you in this, not even Hemingway. If writing style has anything to do about the life through which the writer has passed, it is absolutely true for hemingway. It is believed that he was product of World war. HenryLouis Gates believes Hemingway's style was fundamentally shaped "in reaction to [his] experience of world war". As a reaction to the elaborate flowery style of 19th century writing,  he came out with a style "in which meaning is established through dialogue, through action, and silences—a fiction in which nothing crucial—or at least very little—is stated explicitly." Baker has commented: Hemingway learned to "get the most from the least, how to prune language,how to multiply intensities and how to tell nothing but the truth in a way that allowed for telling more than the truth. Great writings may be influenced but never a copy of someone. Want to know the views of Hemingway himself: 'Live the full life of the mind, exhilarated by new ideas, intoxicated by the romance of unusual.' 'Write hard and clear about what hurts', is another exhortation of Hemingway. There is more pathos when he says: 'There is nothing to writing . All you have to do is to sit before your typewriter and bleed.' But then why copy? Your story would be different, your hurt would be different and different would be the way you would prefer to bleed.   Be original of you rather than copy of Hemingway.
